details.title: Estimation of parameters of life from progressively censored data using Burr-XII model

p: Ahmed A. Soliman was born (1957) in Farshout, Egypt. He received the M.S. in mathematics from Assiut University, Egypt, and Ph.D. in mathematical statistics from South Valley University, Egypt. Now, he is an Associate Professor in the Department of Mathematics Girls College in Makkah, Saudi Arabia. His research interests are in statistical estimation and prediction.

details.abstract: Based on progressively Type-II censored samples, the maximum likelihood, and Bayes estimators for some lifetime parameters (reliability, and hazard functions), as well as the parameters of the Burr-XII model, are derived. The Bayes estimators are obtained using both the symmetric (Squared Error, SE) loss function, and asymmetric (LINEX, and General Entropy, GE) loss functions. This was done with respect to the conjugate prior for the one shape parameter, and discrete prior for the other parameter of this model. Also the existence, uniqueness, and finiteness of the ML parameter estimates for this type of censoring are discussed. A practical example consisting of data from an accelerated test on insulating fluid reported by Nelson (1982) was used for illustration, and comparison. Finally, some numerical results using simulation study concerning different sample sizes, and progressive censoring schemes were reported.

references.title: Progressive censoring: a review

context.text: For a comprehensive recent review of progressive censoring, see [1].
The observations, and the tree-stage removal pattern applied, are reported in Table I, and have been used earlier in [1].

references.text: N. Balakrishnan, C. R. Rao, "Progressive censoring: a review" in Handbook of Statistics. vol. 20 : Advances in Reliability, pp. 373-429, 2001.

references.title: Maximum likelihood estimation of the Laplace parameters based on progressive type-II censored samples

context.text: Many authors have discussed inference under progressive Type-II censored using different lifetime distributions [2], [7], [8], [10], [12], [20], [21], [28].

references.text: N. Balakrishnan, "Maximum likelihood estimation of the Laplace parameters based on progressive type-II censored samples" in Advances in Methods and Applications of Probability and Statistics, 1999, Gordon and Breach Publishers.

references.title: Bayesian estimation of the parameters, reliability and failure rate functions of the Burr type XII failure model

context.text: The usefulness & properties of the Burr XII distribution as a failure model were discussed in many papers [3], [18], [29], [30].

Assuming a bivariate prior density for \$c\$, and for \$k\$, [3] obtained a symmetric Bayes estimates of the parameters, reliability function, and hazard function of the \$Burr(c,k)\$ distribution by using some Bayes approximation forms, and usual Type-II censored sample.

In view of the computational complications arising from a general Bayesian approach [3], [25], it is relevant to consider an alternative approach which may be regarded as an approximation to a more general approach.

references.text: E. K. Al-Hussaini, Z. F. Jaheen, "Bayesian estimation of the parameters reliability and failure rate functions of the Burr type XII failure model", J. Statistical. Computation and Simulation, vol. 41, pp. 31-40, 1992.

references.title: Estimation under the Burr type XII failure model based on censored data: a comparative study

context.text: In [4], Based on Type II censored samples, and assuming that \$c\$ is known, empirical Bayes, and uniformly minimum variance unbiased estimates of parameter \$k\$, and the reliability function, are obtained.

references.text: E. K. Al-Hussaini, M. A. Mousa, Z. F. Jaheen, "Estimation under the Burr type XII failure model based on censored data: a comparative study", Test, vol. 1, pp. 47-60, 1992.

references.title: Point and interval estimation for Gaussian distribution based on progressively type-II censored samples

context.text: Many authors have discussed inference under progressive Type-II censored using different lifetime distributions [2], [7], [8], [10], [12], [20], [21], [28].

links.abstract: The likelihood equations based on a progressively Type-II censored sample from a Gaussian distribution do not provide explicit solutions in any situation except the complete sample case. This paper examines numerically the bias and mean square error of the MLE, and demonstrates that the probability coverages of the pivotal quantities (for location and scale parameters) based on asymptotic s-normality are unsatisfactory, and particularly so when the effective sample size is small. Therefore, this...

references.text: N. Balakrishnan, N. Kannan, C. T. Lin, H. K. T. Ng, "Point and interval estimation for Gaussian distribution based on progressively type-II censored samples", IEEE Trans. Reliab., vol. 52, no. 1, pp. 90-95, 1987.

references.title: Reliability sampling plans for log-normal distribution based on progressively censored samples

context.text: Many authors have discussed inference under progressive Type-II censored using different lifetime distributions [2], [7], [8], [10], [12], [20], [21], [28].

links.abstract: This paper presents reliability sampling plans for the lognormal distribution based on progressively censored samples. In constructing these sampling plans, large-sample approximations to the best linear unbiased estimators of the location and scale parameters are used. For some selected progressive censoring schemes, reliability sampling plans are tabulated for p/sub /spl alpha// and p/sub /spl beta// to match MIL-STD-105. While in general, variable-sampling plans require smaller sample size wh...

references.text: U. Balasooriya, N. Balakrishnan, "Reliability sampling plans for log-normal distribution based on progressively censored samples", IEEE Trans. Reliab., vol. 49, pp. 199-203, 2000.

references.title: Bayesian approach to life testing and reliability estimation using asymmetric loss-function

context.text: For example, in the estimation of reliability & failure rate functions, an overestimate is usually much more serious than an underestimate; in this case the use of a symmetrical loss function might be inappropriate, as has been recognized by [11], [14].
A useful asymmetric loss known as the LINEX loss function, was introduced in [31], and was widely used in several papers [11], [13], [24], [25].

links.abstract: The paper treats a statistical method which allows estimation of Weibull parameters and their confidence limits for progressively-censored aging tests. Estimate of shape and scale parameters is based on a procedure which establishes a relation of the progressively-censored tests performed on a set of specimens with an equivalent singly-censored test, so that the Blom estimator can be used and the later failures of the aging test, which are pertinent to really-aged specimens, acquire a greater we...

references.text: M. Cacciari, G. C. Montanari, "A method to estimate the Weibull parameters for progressively censored tests", IEEE Trans. Reliab., vol. R-36, pp. 87-93, 1987.

references.title: A Bayesian approach to reliability estimation using a loss function

context.text: For example, in the estimation of reliability & failure rate functions, an overestimate is usually much more serious than an underestimate; in this case the use of a symmetrical loss function might be inappropriate, as has been recognized by [11], [14].

links.abstract: A Bayesian estimate of reliability for the exponential case is developed which utilizes the basic notion of loss in estimation theory. Since the loss associated with overestimation is usually greater than the loss associated with underestimation of reliability, the loss function can be a useful tool. The loss function and prior distribution of reliability presented are sufficiently flexible to be compatible with many situations in which reliability estimates are require. When no prior informatio...

references.text: R. V. Canfield, "A Bayesian approach to reliability estimation using a loss function", IEEE Trans. Reliab., vol. R-19, pp. 13-16, 1970.

references.title: Estimators for the 2-parameter Weibull distribution with progressively censored samples

context.text: Many authors have discussed inference under progressive Type-II censored using different lifetime distributions [2], [7], [8], [10], [12], [20], [21], [28].

links.abstract: In many life tests, the initial censoring of items results in withdrawing a portion of the survivors while some remain on test until failure or until a subsequent stage of censoring. If the censoring is progressive through several stages, the resulting sample consists of censored items intermingled with failed ones. The maximum likelihood estimator (MLE) and a least squares median ranks estimator (LSMRE) apply in this situation. Using Monte Carlo methods, the statistical properties of these esti...

references.text: D. I. Gibbons, L. C. Vance, "Estimators for the 2-parameter Weibull distribution with progressively censored samples", IEEE Trans. Reliab., vol. R-32, pp. 95-99, 1983.

references.title: Progressively-censored aging test on XLPE-insulated cable models

context.text: Many authors have discussed inference under progressive Type-II censored using different lifetime distributions [2], [7], [8], [10], [12], [20], [21], [28].

links.abstract: The problem of evaluating the time-to-failure percentiles in progressively-censored tests on solid insulating materials is addressed. Statistical methods to estimate the parameters of the Weibull distribution (and their confidence limits) are examined on the basis of the results of aging with combined thermal-electrical stresses carried out on XLPE insulated cable models. These tests are performed at the same stresses on samples more than 1 m long and subjected to progressive censoring of aging ...

references.text: G. C. Montanari, M. Cacciari, "Progressively-censored aging test on XLPE-insulated cable models", IEEE Trans. Reliab., vol. 23, pp. 365-372, 1988.

references.title: Applied Life Data Analysis

context.text: A practical example consisting of data from an accelerated test on insulating fluid reported by Nelson [22] was used for illustration, and comparison.
Nelson([22]-p 105) reported data on times to breakdown of an insulating fluid between electrodes at a voltage of 34 KV (minutes).
Comparisons are made between the estimators based on a progressively Type-II censored samples consisting of data from an accelerated test on insulating fluid reported in [22].

links.abstract: Presents nearly coincident observations of backscattering from the ERS-1 SAR and of near-surface temperature from drifting buoys in the Beaufort Sea during 1991 and 1992, showing that the onset of melt and fall freeze-up can be detected precisely in the SAR data. Melt onset is marked by a clean steep decrease in backscattering from multiyear ice at 5.3 GHz. The authors show that this decrease is due solely to the appearance of liquid water in snow covering the multiyear ice. Freeze-up is marked ...

references.text: W. Nelson, Applied Life Data Analysis, 1982, John Wiley.

references.title: Bayesian analysis of the Weibull process with unknown scale and shape parameters

context.text: In this paper, we consider the method advocated by [23], where \$c\$ is restricted to a finite number of values \$c_{1},c_{2},\ldots,c_{N}\$. with prior probabilities \$\eta_{1},\eta_{2},\ldots,\eta_{N}\$ respectively, where \$0\leq\eta_{j}\leq1\$, and \$\sum_{.j=1}^{N}\eta_{j}=1\$. (i.e. \$Pr(c=cj)=\eta_{j}\$).

links.abstract: Previously, the Weibull process with an unknown scale parameter was examined as a model for Bayesian decision making. The analysis is extended by treating both the shape and scale parameters as unknown. It is not possible to find a family of continuous joint prior distributions on the two parameters that is closed under sampling, so a family of prior distributions is used that places continuous distributions on the scale parameter and discrete distributions on the shape parameter. Prior and post...

references.text: R. M. Soland, "Bayesian analysis of the Weibull process with unknown scale and shape parameters", IEEE Trans. Reliab., vol. R-18, pp. 181-184, 1969.

context.text: A useful asymmetric loss known as the LINEX loss function, was introduced in [31], and was widely used in several papers [11], [13], [24], [25].
In [25], various estimators of Sf of the \$Burr(c,k)\$, as a member of a generalized life-model, were obtained.

In view of the computational complications arising from a general Bayesian approach [3], [25], it is relevant to consider an alternative approach which may be regarded as an approximation to a more general approach.

links.abstract: Estimators of the reliability function in a GLM (generalized life model) are considered. The class of the GLM includes (among others) the Weibull, Pareto, Beta, Gompertz, and Rayleigh distribution. A proper general prior density and the predictive function for general class of distribution proposed by Al-Hussaini(1999) are used to obtain the exact estimate. Also, the Bayes estimates relative to symmetric loss function (quadratic loss), and asymmetric loss function (LINEX loss, and GE loss), are ...

references.text: A. A. Soliman, "Reliability estimation in a generalized life-model with application to the Burr-XII", IEEE Trans. Reliab., vol. 51, no. 3, pp. 337-343, 2002.

references.title: Solution of the three-parameter Weibull equations by constrained modified quasilinearization (progressively censored samples)

links.abstract: The location, shape, and scale parameters of the Weibull distribution are estimated from Type I progressively censored samples by the method of maximum likelihood. Nonlinear logarithmic likelihood estimating equations are derived, and the approximate asymptotic variance-covariance matrix for the maximum likelihood parameter estimates is given. The iterative procedure to solve the likelihood equations is a stable and rapidly convergent constrained modified quasilinearization algorithm which is ap...

references.text: D. R. Wingo, "Solution of the three-parameter Weibull equations by constrained modified quasilinearization (progressively censored samples)", IEEE Trans. Reliab., vol. R-22, pp. 96-102, 1973.

A useful asymmetric loss known as the LINEX loss function, was introduced in [31], and was widely used in several papers [11], [13], [24], [25].
